final-project-notes.html.title: Final Project Notes
final-project-notes.html.description:
Roguelike
Either turn-based or projectile-based combat
Progress up the tower, each level has a different enemy to fight
Win once you reach the top of the tower (3-4 levels)
20 minutes of gameplay maximum
Game assets should have a kind of cute pixelated vibe
4 characters to choose from initially with different classes. Ideas:
Rogue (Lower health, higher speed)
Warrior (Higher health, lower speed)
Ability to customize armour / weapon colours, maybe add a symbol on chestplate?
Could cycle through presets like star, heart, etc.
Tower with 3-4 levels
Open to the outdoors
Elegant vibe, white marble or cobblestone
Ground becomes farther away as you progress each level
Should drop coins and/or items, not guaranteed drop, typical loot mechanics
Can maybe look into Pokemon games for move ideas
Fire boss (Jayda) Dragon
Bear (sun vibes?) Water boss (Jayce) Reptile?
Zebak mechanics (dont worry about this it's jayce's problem) Poison boss (Shannon) Venus fly trap?
Scorpion
Snake / reptile Can sell loot from bosses for gold coins
Use gold to buy items. Current items: Health pot
Maybe better armour / weapons? Theming / Skins
Player will be able to customize their armour colour / symbol
Advanced Computer AI
Boss could check the armour of the player and adjust accordingly Example: If using fire resistant armour, boss starts using water-based attacks
Detailed Statistics
Add timer for the run
Favourite attack
Alternate Rulesets / Modes
Newgame+
Endless mode, difficulty scales up exponentially Your game must be fully playable and implement a clear ruleset or system. If the rules arenâ€™t common knowledge, be ready to provide your professor with reference material for the rules. Gameplay constraints like turn order/timing, collision, timing, legal plays, etc. need to be enforced. The player should be able to win or lose. Depending on genre, this may include turnâ€‘based decisionâ€‘making (cards, board games), pathing, movement, or attack selection (tower defense, waveâ€‘based games), enemy spawning and behaviour logic (anything besides cards), NPC interactions (RPGs). Some form of basic, rulesâ€‘based AI is required.Your project must include a GUI. It should generally be clean and functional for an average person to use. It should be accessible (with mindfulness to contrast, readable text, and keyboard friendliness) and appropriate to the type of game. Your solution must somehow demonstrate the four pillars of OOP: encapsulation, abstraction, inheritance and polymorphism. It will very likely also use a library and collections in some way. The code should generally be wellâ€‘organized (e.g. use of regions, folders, and careful naming conventions). The code body should have comment headers on all humanâ€‘generated code files/classes and meaningful comments throughout. Documentation structures that lend themselves to better development and organization, such as docstrings in Python, Javadoc in Java, or XML. Comments in C# are strongly recommended. While a style guide is not prescribed in this course, the group should agree on a style guide and adhere to it. Your finished project should include some form of user guide or tutorial. This can take many forms including a separate document, a short video, or thorough inline help in the game. This should include how to play, a guide to the controls, and an explanation of any settings/options. GitHub â€“ or an approved alternative â€“ needs to be used for source control and collaboration. As well, a GitHub Project board or another Kanban tool is essential and should be referred to and maintained from at least Weekâ€¯4 onward As noted previously, not every optional feature will make sense for every genre of game so choose options that are appropriate. Create a more advanced computer AI that would make alternate choices rather than the default strategy; something beyond strict rule adherence so that the opponents are more responsive, and more difficult to predict and defeat Either add distinct difficulty settings, or make it so that the game becomes harder (or easier) based on time, player actions, or progress. Create planned variation in the opponents the player can encounter. Perhaps they appear and behave differently. Note that this is not a suitable optional rule to select for an RPG since having a single enemy type would be silly. Make selectable variant rules to a wellâ€‘defined game, such as alternate cards (e.g. jokers in play, wildcards) or pieces, or different board layouts. Some game styles may lend themselves well to an endless mode, or a puzzle mode. Allow several playerâ€‘selectable UI or visual themes. Record and update the human playerâ€™s name and the number of games played, won, lost, or tied, in addition to the current streak (win, lose, or tie) / ratio. This should be persistent: meaning it needs to be saved in an external file and loaded each time the player plays the game again. An option for the player to reset the statistics should be made available. Allow for basic multiplayer gameplay between different players running the software on different devices. Students may propose their own optional feature, but it must be discussed with and approved by the professor no later than the end of Weekâ€¯10 to ensure that its scope is suitable as an optional feature.

info_showCustomIcons.description: Show custom icons for files and folders

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
